Subject: The project will finance the rolling out of fixed and wireless broadband services and upgrading of Ooredoo�s mobile telecommunications networks in Myanmar. The project is being developed under a 15-year operating and associated spectrum license on a build�own�operate basis that authorizes Ooredoo to provide a full range of fixed and mobile telecommunications services nationwide.The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.This document dated January 2019 is provided for the ADB project 52200-001 in Myanmar.
Title: Nationwide Data Connectivity Project: Report and Recommendation of the President

to the Board of Directors

January 2019 
 
 
 
Proposed Loan 
Ooredoo Q.P.S.C.

(Myanmar)

Information Policy.

2. 
 
 

 

  PROJECT AT A GLANCE 

 

 

 
 

 

  I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan of 
up to $500,000,000 to Ooredoo Q.P.S.C. (Ooredoo) for the Nationwide Data Connectivity Project 
in Myanmar. 
 
2. 
The  loan  will  finance  the  rolling  out  of  fixed  and  wireless  broadband  services  and 
upgrading of Ooredoo’s mobile telecommunications networks in Myanmar.1 The project is being 
developed under a 15-year operating and associated spectrum license on a build–own–operate 
basis  that  authorizes  Ooredoo  to  provide  a  full  range  of  fixed  and  mobile  telecommunications 
services nationwide. The project will benefit the Myanmar population by increasing the availability 
and quality of telecommunications and data connectivity services throughout the country, which 
will  lead  to  greater  sustainable  socioeconomic  growth  and  poverty  reduction.  As  a  project 
classified  gender  equity  as  a  theme,  it  will  advance  inclusive  sustainable  development  by 
promoting  the  use  of  information  and  communication  technology  (ICT)  in  support  of  gender 
equality and women’s empowerment. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Project Identification and Description 

 
A. 
 
3. 
Project  identification.  Universal  access  to  ICT  is  critical  in  fostering  a  country’s 
socioeconomic growth and is at the heart of economic growth and development. In addition to the 
direct benefits, scaling up investments in telecommunications infrastructure will (i) improve access 
to  domestic  and  regional  markets,  (ii)  attract  private  investment,  (iii)  reduce  urban–rural 
development  gaps,  and  (iv)  help  reap  gains  from  regional  connectivity  and  integration.  The 
expansion  of  telecommunications  coverage  in  remote  villages  will  provide  the  rural  poor  with 
mobile and data access to enable better communication with families and communities; access 
to information, news, and education; and better delivery of government services. Overall, this will 
stimulate  economic  development,  providing  access  to  improved  jobs  and  small-to-medium 
business opportunities. 

 

Decades of isolation have led Myanmar to become one of the least connected countries 
4. 
in Southeast Asia—for every 100 people, only seven had access to a mobile phone, 0.5 had fixed 
telephone lines, and 0.7 had a broadband internet subscription in 2013.2 Myanmar liberalized its 
mobile telecommunications market in 2013, opening it to foreign investment. Following one of the 
most competitive international tenders with more than 90 applicants, the Government of Myanmar 
awarded  telecommunications  operating  and  associated  spectrum  licenses  to  Qatar's  Ooredoo 
and Norway's Telenor Group in June 2013. Since then, there has been a significant change to 
the telecommunications industry with the mobile penetration rate rising from 7% in 2013 to nearly 
90%  in  2017.  By  the  end  of  2017,  the  number  of  mobile  subscribers  in  Myanmar  reached  50 
million,  and  smartphone  penetration  rates  soared  to  more  than  70%  of  the  country’s  mobile 
connections. 
 
Although  Myanmar's  telecommunications  market  leapfrogged  from  analog  to  the  digital 
5. 
era  in  a  short  period  of  time,  substantial  investments  are  required  to  upgrade  its  mobile 
                                                
1  Ooredoo provides nationwide coverage of second- and third-generation mobile telecommunications networks, and 

is rolling out a fourth-generation (4G) mobile telecommunications network across the country. 

2  Government  of  Myanmar,  Ministry  of  Transport  and  Communications.  2013. 

Information  Memorandum 

(Telecommunications Operator Tender Evaluation and Selection Committee). Nay Pyi Taw. 

 

 

 

 telecommunications  networks,  including  the  nationwide  rollout  of  a  fourth-generation  (4G) 
network, to enhance their speed and capacity for transferring data. This will enable broadband 
internet,  e-mail,  and  enriched  mobile  applications  in  addition  to  conventional  voice  and  text 
services.  Furthermore,  as  the  broadband  market  remains  highly  underdeveloped  with  a 
penetration  rate  of  less  than  2%,  rapid  expansion  of  fixed  and  wireless broadband  services  is 
required to cater to the exponential increase in demand for data connectivity from businesses and 
households. 
 
The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  identified  the  opportunity  of  providing  financial 
6. 
assistance to Ooredoo to support its expansion into fixed and wireless broadband services and 
the upgrade of its mobile telecommunications networks through proactive engagement and strong 
relationships with key telecommunications players in Myanmar. The goal is to implement ADB’s 
Strategy  2030  and  country  partnership  strategy,  2017–2021  for  Myanmar,  which  emphasize 
support  for  private  sector  participation  in  infrastructure  projects  in  new  communication 
technologies and the mobilization of private sector resources for innovation and job creation.3 By 
assisting Ooredoo in its next phase of expansion, ADB is supporting the company’s drive toward 
enhancing data connectivity in Myanmar, which is the next phase of development after completing 
the rollout of basic telecommunications infrastructure that provides conventional voice and text 
services. 
 
CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED 
 
7. 
 
 
8. 
Borrower. Headquartered in Qatar and established in 1987, Ooredoo is a leading global 
telecommunications company that serves almost 130 million customers. Ooredoo has significant 
geographic diversification, with operations in 10 markets across Asia, the Middle East, and North 
Africa. Ooredoo has leading market positions in most of the markets in which it operates. It was 
47th in Brand Finance’s list of the world’s 500 most valuable telecommunications brands in 2017.4 
 
CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED 
 
B. 
 
9. 
Impacts. The project will improve access to quality telecommunications services and will 
also contribute to raising the mobile and broadband internet  penetration rates to enable better 
access to information, knowledge, and social and economic opportunities. Through ADB’s active 
engagement  in  incorporating  gender  elements  into  the  project  design,  the  project  (classified 
gender equity as a theme) will promote gender-equitable access; facilitate inclusive growth and 
poverty reduction; and contribute to the National Strategic Plan for the Advancement of Women, 
which calls for improving systems, structures, and practices to ensure women’s equal participation 
in decision making and leadership at all levels of society.5 
 

Project design. CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED 

Development Impacts, Outcome, and Outputs 

                                                
3  ADB.  2018.  Strategy  2030:  Achieving  a  Prosperous,  Inclusive,  Resilient,  and  Sustainable  Asia  and  the  Pacific. 
Manila; and ADB. 2017. Country Partnership Strategy: Myanmar, 2017–2021—Building the Foundations for Inclusive 
Growth. Manila. 

4  Brand Finance. 2017. Telecoms 500, 2017: The annual report on the world’s most valuable telecoms brands. London. 
5  Government  of  Myanmar;  Ministry  of  Social  Welfare,  Relief  and  Resettlement;  Department  of  Social  Welfare. 

National Strategic Plan for the Advancement of Women (2013–2022). Nay Pyi Taw. 

2 

 

 3 

Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 

Outcome.  The  project’s  outcome  is  improved  and  more  gender-inclusive  mobile 

10. 
telecommunications and broadband coverage. 
 
11. 
Outputs.  The  project’s  outputs  will  be  the  (i)  extended  4G  mobile  telecommunications 
network  and  fixed  and  wireless  broadband  networks,  (ii)  enabling  environment  for  achieving 
gender equality in job opportunities created, and (iii) implemented corporate social responsibility 
and community development initiatives focusing on women’s empowerment. 
 
C. 
 
12. 
Consistency with ADB strategy. ADB’s assistance for the project is aligned with ADB’s 
long-term corporate strategy  (Strategy 2030), which identifies gender equality as one of seven 
operational  priority  areas.  Strategy  2030  also  emphasizes  private  sector  participation  in 
infrastructure projects in new communication technologies and the mobilization of private sector 
resources for innovation and job creation. 
 
Consistency with country strategy. The assistance is also aligned with ADB’s country 
13. 
partnership strategy, 2017–2021 and country operations business plan, 2017–2019 for Myanmar, 
as the project promotes the private sector as an engine of growth for inclusive and sustainable 
development, enables access and connectivity to address critical infrastructure needs, connects 
rural and urban areas and markets, and provides access to basic social services such as mobile 
banking and smart agriculture.6 
 
14. 
Lessons  from  previous  operations.  The  Private  Sector  Operations  Department’s 
extended annual review of phases 1–3 of the Roshan Cellular Telecommunications Project found 
the presence of underserved populations to be the main driver of growth in telecommunications 
in Afghanistan; it rated ADB’s private sector development impact excellent as Roshan’s mobile 
subscriber base grew from 158,000 in 2004 to 5 million in 2011 with greatly increased coverage.7 
ADB’s  previous  operations  in  nascent  and  frontier  telecommunications  markets  such  as 
Afghanistan and Myanmar (footnote 5) show that (i) infrastructure investments led by the private 
sector can be undertaken successfully and sustained in sectors that promote market competition 
and transparency and (ii) ADB’s continuous and active engagement has a strong catalytic and 
development impact in promoting private sector investment and healthy competition. 
 
D. 
 
CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED 
 
E. 
 
15. 
 

Table 3 summarizes the implementation arrangements.8

authority for the telecommunications sector in Myanmar, and the Posts 
and Telecommunications Department (PTD) under the MOTC is the

main regulator for telecommunications sector. The operating and 
associated spectrum license is structured on a build–own–operate basis 
that authorizes the operator to provide a full range of fixed and mobile 
telecommunications services on a nationwide basis for 15 years with an 
option to renew for another 15 years. 
The project will be managed by Ooredoo Q.P.S.C., a leading global 
telecommunications company that delivers mobile, fixed, and broadband 
internet services to more than 130 million customers in 10 countries.

F. 
 
CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED 
 

III. 

THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 

The Assistance 

Value Added by ADB Assistance 

in  Myanmar,  and  will  catalyze  other  private  sector 

 
A. 
 
CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED  
 
B. 
 
16. 
ADB’s  continued  support  and  engagement  with  the  telecommunications  sector  in 
Myanmar  will  have  a  strong  demonstration  impact  on  other  multinational  and  international 
financiers in proving that infrastructure investments led by the private sector can be undertaken 
the 
successfully 
telecommunications sector in Myanmar. 
 
The  project,  classified  gender  equity  as  a  theme,  builds  on  the  success  of  ADB’s  first 
17. 
assistance to Ooredoo (para. 7). ADB’s active engagement in incorporating gender elements into 
the  project  design  has  resulted  in  Ooredoo  further  expanding  its  commitment  to  support  and 
advance  inclusive  sustainable  development  by  promoting  the  use  of  ICT  in  supporting  gender 
equality and women’s empowerment. The project aims to reduce the gender gap by facilitating 
women’s basic access to ICT and providing ICT jobs, promotion, training, and health services to 
women.  ADB’s  assistance  will  also  ensure  that  Ooredoo  fully  adopts  and  implements  ADB’s 
environmental and social safeguards standards, which exceed the national standards. 
 
C. 
 
CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED

 5 

IV. 

POLICY COMPLIANCE 

for

Safeguards and Social Dimensions 

The project is processed as general corporate finance, with ADB funds expected to be 
the  expansion  and  upgrade  of  Ooredoo  Myanmar’s  nationwide  mobile 

 
A. 
 
18. 
allocated 
telecommunications network in Myanmar.  
 
CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED 
 
B. 
 
Ooredoo was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practice relating 
19. 
to combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB will ensure that 
the  investment  documentation  includes  appropriate  provisions  prohibiting  corruption,  money 
laundering, and the financing of terrorism; and remedies for ADB in the event of noncompliance. 
 
C. 
 
CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED  
 
D. 
 
Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter),9 
20. 
ADB  will  proceed  with  the  proposed  assistance  upon  establishing  that  the  Government  of 
Myanmar has no objection to the proposed assistance to Ooredoo. ADB will enter into suitable 
finance  documentation,  in  form  and  substance  satisfactory  to  ADB,  following  approval  of  the 
proposed assistance by the Board of Directors. 
 

Investment Limitations 

Assurances 

V. 

RECOMMENDATION 

 
21. 
I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  of  up  to 
$500,000,000  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources  to  Ooredoo  Q.P.S.C.  for  the  Nationwide 
Data  Connectivity  Project  in  Myanmar,  with  such  terms  and  conditions  as  are  substantially  in 
accordance with those set forth in this report, and as may be reported to the Board. 

28 January 2019 

 
 
 
Takehiko Nakao 
President 

                                                
9  ADB. 1966. Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank. Manila.
